nodes.bodyText: Is this all about?
consider marking this constructor as @Deprecated.
This is the only non-deprecated constructor here.

Consider to revert condition in naming:
int getRequiredColumnSize() -> int getColumnSize() 
Optional<Integer> getColumnSize() -> Optional<Integer> getOptionalColumnSize()

As it is more inline with standard java naming.
And according to commit message: The COLUMN_SIZE field is null in **some** cases, so only in that some cases we will have longer getOptionalColumnSize()

consistent with https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/ece62ab29bc96a723669687e17bc2eef183a2d4d/presto-base-jdbc/src/main/java/io/prestosql/plugin/jdbc/JdbcTypeHandle.java#L88-L98
also, since the new getRequiredColumnSize is not a drop in replacement for the old method, i want anyone using this class to update their code, rather than blindly continue to call same method, but with a different behavior.

Personally, I'd rename it to something like getColumnSizeOrThrow to be closer to Optional.orElseThrow.
It's not quite clear from the name what the semantics of getRequiredColumnSize are.
(I'd say the same about getRequiredDecimalDigits.)

preexisting, so let's keep compatible with existing name for  now and we can change both if we want to
other name proposal is getExisting.......  not sure.

And according to commit message: The COLUMN_SIZE field is null in some cases, so only in that some cases we will have longer getOptionalColumnSize()

That's interesting, but i am concerned about implicit validating happening within a method that looks like ordinary getter ("getColumnSize").

I had the same idea like @jirassimok -> but had the feeling it could mislead a user a little bit as well -> and maybe with such name it's already better to inline this method -> but there are a lot of occurrences -> goto begin.
But as long this idea came to someone else I'd vote for it.

I personally do not like "OrThrow" in method names. I want the method to declare semantics ("something is required"), rather than describe implementation ("i will throw").
Anyway, i think both names are OK names, but one is existing (getRequiredDecimalDigits) and I do not want to change this within this PR.
The change int getColumnSize to Optional getColumnSize is already a problem to accommodate to for anyone depending on this code.
the code here relied on NULL being represented as 0.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -279,7 +279,7 @@ protected String getTableSchemaName(ResultSet resultSet)
             case NVARCHAR:
             case LONGVARCHAR:
             case LONGNVARCHAR:
-                if (typeHandle.getRequiredColumnSize() == 0) {

nodes.bodyText: Maybe there should be makeTypeHandle(int, String, int) in this class to make this simpler to read and easier to change.

in this class -- could be.
however, i dont want to introduce a public API into JdbcTypeHandle... maybe a builder would be nice (but wouldn't improve this particular place)
I agree—this is the only place where we construct so many JdbcTypeHandle (and with so many duplicate arguments).

maybe it is just me, but I find it hard to read code using Optional#filter. That's too clever for me.
(i have no problem writing such code though)

For one this simple, I think it's readable, and the pattern is easy to learn, but it's a matter of taste. (And for anything more complicated (like the mapping for char), it's a definitely bad idea.)
I still prefer using Optional chaining, but this might be a more readable way to do that, or you could leave it as-is.
return type.getColumnSize()
    .map(length ->
        length <= VarcharType.MAX_LENGTH
            ? createVarcharType(length)
            : createUnboundedVarcharType())
    .map(StandardColumnMappings::varcharColumnMapping)
(Though neither this nor the current solution works if any JDBC supports unbounded varchar and reports them as having null column size. I assume we don't know any such JDBC.)

Why use both conditions instead of checking charLength <= CharType.MAX_LENGTH and otherwise falling through to the VARCHAR case?
The char mapping could be modified to use the Optional version of getColumnSize, but it's not as nice as it is for varchar.
return type.getOptionalColumnSize()
        .filter(length -> length <= CharType.MAX_LENGTH)
        .map(length -> charColumnMapping(createCharType(length)))
        .or(() -> type.getOptionalColumnSize()
                .filter(length -> length <= VarcharType.MAX_LENGTH)
                .map(length -> varcharColumnMapping(createVarcharType(length)))
                .or(() -> Optional.of(varcharColumnMapping(createUnboundedVarcharType()))));
In case of char, the length must be present. It's erroneous to have a char, but not know its length.
Maybe fullPrecision would be a better name? (Doesn't matter either way.)
"actualPrecision"? "originalPrecision"?
Anything like that works, but "oraclePrecision" doesn't capture the right semantics.
changed to actualPrecision
